user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_to_uint64_n_:
```c
size_t
MHD_str_to_uint64_n_ (const char *str,
                      size_t maxlen,
                      uint64_t *out_val)
{
  uint64_t res;
  size_t i;

  if (! str || ! maxlen || ! out_val || ! isasciidigit (str[0]))
    return 0;

  res = 0;
  i = 0;
  do
  {
    const int digit = (unsigned char) str[i] - '0';

    if ( (res > (UINT64_MAX / 10)) ||
         ( (res == (UINT64_MAX / 10)) &&
           ((uint64_t) digit > (UINT64_MAX % 10)) ) )
      return 0;

    res *= 10;
    res += (unsigned int) digit;
    i++;
  } while ( (i < maxlen) &&
            isasciidigit (str[i]) );

  *out_val = res;
  return i;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_str_to_uint64_n_:
_MHD_static_inline bool
isasciidigit (char c)
{
  return (c >= '0') && (c <= '9');
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments that modify any function parameter variables. Specifically:
- The pointer parameters are str (const char *), and out_val (uint64_t *). There is no assignment to str or out_val anywhere in the function (no pointer reassignment, no pointer arithmetic that updates the parameter). The function only indexes str (str[i]) and casts its character value; indexing and casting do not modify the pointer parameter itself.
- The value stored via the pointer parameter is *out_val = res; this modifies the object pointed to by out_val, which is permitted by the rule (the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified). The pointer variable out_val itself is not changed.
- The scalar parameter maxlen is only read (tested and compared), not assigned to or modified.
- The helper isasciidigit(char c) takes its argument by value and does not modify the caller's parameter.
- All other assignments update local variables (res, i, digit), not any of the function parameters.

Therefore, there are no fragments that should be investigated for potential violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the provided code.
